dataset.shortName: Sycamore Creek: Resilience, Distribution and abundance
dataset.title: Sycamore Creek Wetland Abundance and Distribution Changes, Phoenix Arizona, 2010 to 2013

abstract.para: The primary objective of this project is to understand how long-term climate variability and change influence the structure and function of desert streams via effects on hydrologic disturbance regimes. Climate and hydrology are intimately linked in arid landscapes; for this reason, desert streams are particularly well suited for both observing and understanding the consequences of climate variability and directional change. Researchers try to (1) determine how climate variability and change over multiple years influence stream biogeomorphic structure (i.e., prevalence and persistence of wetland and gravel-bed ecosystem states) via their influence on factors that control vegetation biomass, and (2) compare interannual variability in within-year successional patterns in ecosystem processes and community structure of primary producers and consumers of two contrasting reach types (wetland and gravel-bed stream reaches). This specific dataset was collected to understand (1) the spatial pattern of wetland distribution and abundance; (2) the influence of multi-annual variability in hydrological regime on wetland distribution and abundance; and (3) the mechanism of the resilience of wetland to different disturbances in terms of hydrology (i.e., drying and flood).

keywordSet.keyword: central arizona phoenix longterm ecological research
biogeochemical patterns, processes, and human outcomes
keywordSet.keywordThesaurus: IPA and Core Area CAP Data Portal Controler

section.para: Copyright Board of Regents, Arizona State University. This information is released to the public and may be used for academic, educational, or commercial purposes subject to the following restrictions:

listitem.para: While CAP LTER will make every effort possible to control and document the quality of the data it publishes, the data are made available 'as is'.
CAP LTER cannot assume responsibility for damages resulting from mis-use or mis-interpretation of datasets or from errors or omissions that may exist in the data.
It is considered a matter of professional ethics to acknowledge the work of other scientists that has resulted in data used in subsequent research.
CAP LTER expects that any use of data from this server will be accompanied with the appropriate citations and acknowledgments.

CAP LTER encourages users to contact the original investigator responsible for the data that they are accessing. Where appropriate, researchers whose projects are integrally dependent on CAP LTER data are encouraged to consider collaboration and/or co-authorship with original investigators.
CAP LTER requests that users submit to the Global Institute of Sustainability, ASU, one copy of any publication resulting from the use of data obtained from this site.
CAP LTER requests that users not redistribute data obtained from this site. However, links or references to this site may be freely posted.

description.para: The Sycamore Creek is a Longterm Research Site, research will be ongoing

contact.organizationName: Global Institute of Sustainability, Arizona State University

section.title: METHOD DESCRIPTION:
section.para: We collected data every year between 2009 and 2013 on June 15 ± 1 day. The basic procedures are as follows:

listitem.para: Start at known point, pace off 25 m, record stream and channel substrata and presence-absence of a) cyanobacterial mats or Nostoc; b) wetland vegetation (see list *Method Notes below). Repeat. Check and reset pace with hand-held GPS.
Establish several points (every 200-400 m or so) where all three GPS’s are recorded at same spot.
Discontinue recording at dry segments; record location of surface water end.
Re-start presence/absence recording at tops of wet segments; record location.
Works with Team 2 to locate sites and record data
Takes photos and records notes
Determine start and end of surface water, ciénegas.
Measure width, length, plant height and plant density in ciénega patches >2 x 2 m, and the species
Measure the water depths of wetland patches and estimate water coverage of the wetland patch (this was only done starting 2011)
If the whole patch is in the surface water, measure the water depth of the central point of the patch;
If the patch is partly in the surface water, (1) estimate the percentage of the patch in the water; and (2) measure the water depth at the central point of part of the patch in the water.
If the whole patch is out of the surface water, record water depth as “0”

section.title: *Method Notes:
section.para: In different surveys, the set of variables surveyed might be different.

listitem.para: water depth measured for presence/absence data: the water depth was the average water depth across the transect every 25m.
water depth measured for patch data: the water depth was the average water depth within the wetland patch.
Water cover measured for patch data: the percentage of each wetland patch that is covered by water.
PADI: Paspalum distichum – knotgrass
SCAM: Schoenoplectus americanus – chairmaker’s bulrush
EQLA: Equisetum laevigatum – horsetail reed
TYDO: Typha domingensis – cattail
JUTO: Juncus torreyi - Torrey's rush
SCACO2: Schoenoplectus acutus occidentalis - Tule
CYOD: Cyperus odoratus - fragrant flatsedge
PHAU: Phacelia austromontana

project.title: Long-term climate variability and ecosystem response in a desert stream, Sycamore Creek AZ.

abstract.para: The primary objective of this project is to understand how long-term climate variability influences the structure and function of desert streams. Climate and hydrology are intimately linked in arid landscapes; for this reason, desert streams, such as our study sites at Sycamore Creek, AZ, are particularly well suited for both observing and understanding the consequences of climate variability and directional change. Arid regions are characterized by high interannual variation in precipitation, and these climate patterns drive the overall disturbance regime (in terms of flooding and drying) and nutrient status of desert stream ecosystems. At long time scales, the number and size of floods in a given year or cluster of years dictate nutrient delivery to streams from the surrounding catchment, and also influence the biogeomorphic structure of the stream-riparian corridor. Embedded within this decadal-scale hydrologic regime, flash floods scour stream channels and initiate a series of rapid successional changes by benthic algae and macroinvertebrates at short time scales (i.e., within a year). An important goal of this research is to determine how recovery following discrete events is influenced by both stream nutrient status and channel structure and to thus better understand how long-term climate variability and change guide the interactions among slow (biogeomorphic change) and fast (post-flood succession) features and processes characteristic of desert stream ecosystems.

one of the following: P= pool (slow, deep, L>W); F=riffle (fast, turbulent, coarse sediment); N=run (otherwise)
Maximum water depths: Unit: (cm)

Stream substrata; one of the following options: S=Sand (S<0.2cm), G=Gravel (between 0.2cm to 6.4cm), C=Cobble (6.4cm to 25.6cm), B=Boulder (25.6cm to 400cm), R=Bedrock (>400cm); if S/B, it means both sand and boulder exist, but more sand than boulder. Same for other combinations.

codeDefinition.definition: Both sand and boulder exist, but more sand than boulder.

ns2:unit.name: stems per meter square
ns2:unit.ns2:description: Count of the stems divided by the area in square meters, is a population density.
